newsitem.title: UK: UK Labour reaffirms commitment to cut VAT on fuel.
newsitem.headline: UK Labour reaffirms commitment to cut VAT on fuel.

text.p: Britain's main opposition Labour party on Monday reaffirmed its promise to reduce value added tax (VAT) on domestic gas and electricity bills to five percent from eight percent if it wins the next general election.
"Unless VAT on fuel is cut to five percent the budget will have failed the fairness test," Labour's economics spokesman, Gordon Brown, said.

"And if the Conservatives do not cut fuel in this budget, new Labour will make it a manifesto commitment," Brown, speaking at the unveiling of a new poster attacking the ruling Conservatives for a succession of VAT increases, said.

He also challenged Chancellor of the Exchequer Kenneth Clarke to admit that the Conservatives would raise VAT on fuel to 17.5 percent if they won re-election. A similar proposal in the 1994 budget was defeated by Labour and Conservative rebels.
Brown contrasted what he called Conservative dishonesty and unfairness on tax with the "fairness" of Labour, which he said would "build a new trust in tax".
